3) We must get across the idea that
learning is important to the in¬
dividual.
4) We must create a learning situation
in which "success" does occur each
day, in every class.
5) We must create an environment in
which each "success" is reinforced,
so that those experiences become
cumulative.
6) We have to convince the individual
that it is possible for him to "work
through failure" to success.
The transposition of these ideas to the television
teaching situation, for example, could be des¬
cribed in this way:
A child who sees another child dealing with
the same materials he deals with, may, more
readily, come to identify with another child's
"failures and successes" when those ex¬
periences are similar to his own. When this
occurs, when this process of "identification"
is achieved, then the closest thing to "total
learning" will have been achieved. This is
